Digitalization of tax administration refers to the use of digital technologies to facilitate tax collection and management processes. This includes the use of digital platforms for taxpayer registration, filing and payment of taxes, and data analysis for tax compliance monitoring. In Sub-Saharan Africa (SSA), tax digitalization has gained momentum in recent years due to the need to improve tax collection and revenue mobilization, as well as to enhance transparency and accountability in the tax system.

The impact of tax digitalization on tax revenues in SSA has been the subject of various studies. Bassongui and Houngbédji (2022) conducted a systematic review of the literature on the impacts of tax digitalization on tax revenues in SSA and found that tax digitalization has a positive effect on tax revenues, especially in countries with high levels of mobile phone and internet penetration. They noted that tax digitalization can improve tax compliance by making tax payment and filing processes more convenient and accessible to taxpayers.

Similarly, Bassey, Mulligan, and Ojo (2022) proposed a conceptual framework for digital tax administration in SSA based on a systematic review of the literature. They identified key factors that influence the adoption and effectiveness of digital tax administration, including legal and regulatory frameworks, infrastructure and technology, human capacity, and stakeholder engagement. They emphasized the importance of a collaborative approach to digital tax administration that involves all relevant stakeholders, including taxpayers, tax authorities, and technology providers.

However, the adoption of tax digitalization in SSA is not without challenges. Mpofu (2022) highlights some of the challenges faced by African countries in implementing digital taxation, such as the lack of digital infrastructure and human capacity, inadequate legal and regulatory frameworks, and resistance to change by taxpayers and tax administrators. He also notes that the taxation of the digital economy presents a significant challenge due to the difficulty in identifying and taxing digital services that cross national borders.

The COVID-19 pandemic has accelerated the adoption of tax digitalization in SSA, with many countries adopting digital tax administration to facilitate remote tax filing and payment. Arthur, Hanson, and Puplampu (2021) discuss the impact of the pandemic on revenue mobilization, taxation, and the digital economy in SSA. They note that the pandemic has highlighted the need for robust and resilient tax systems that can adapt to changing circumstances, and that tax digitalization can play a critical role in this regard.

In conclusion, tax digitalization has the potential to improve tax collection and revenue mobilization in SSA. However, its adoption and effectiveness depend on a range of factors, including legal and regulatory frameworks, infrastructure and technology, human capacity, and stakeholder engagement. To ensure the successful implementation of digital tax administration in SSA, policymakers and tax administrators must address these factors and adopt a collaborative and adaptive approach to tax digitalization.

Introduction:
Digitalization refers to the use of digital technologies and platforms to enhance, simplify and automate processes, activities and services in various fields, including taxation. The provision of technologies for digitalization of tax administration in Sub-Saharan Africa has been a topic of interest in recent years. This review seeks to explore the impacts, benefits, challenges, and promises of digital technologies in enhancing tax collection and administration in Sub-Saharan Africa.

Impacts of Digitalization on Tax Administration in Sub-Saharan Africa:
Several studies have shown that digital technologies have had a positive impact on tax administration in Sub-Saharan Africa. Okunogbe and Santoro (2023) suggested that the use of information technology (IT) has the potential to increase tax collection and improve revenue mobilization in African countries. They argued that the adoption of digital platforms and technologies could enhance tax compliance, simplify tax procedures, and reduce the cost of tax administration. In a similar vein, Bernad et al. (2023) highlighted the potential of digital merchant payments as a medium of tax compliance, which could reduce the incidence of tax evasion and boost tax collection.

Challenges and Limitations of Digitalization:
While digitalization presents numerous benefits for tax administration, there are also challenges and limitations that must be addressed. Bakibinga-Gaswaga et al. (2020) identified policy gaps, inadequate infrastructure, limited access to digital technologies, and lack of digital literacy as major challenges facing the adoption of digital technologies in Africa. Similarly, Iddrisu (2023) noted that digitalization could exacerbate inequality and exclusion if not well-implemented. In the same vein, Nguimkeu and Okou (2021) highlighted the challenges of integrating informal sector players into digital platforms, as they lack formal identification and access to digital platforms.

Promises and Opportunities of Digitalization:
Digitalization presents numerous promises and opportunities for tax administration in Sub-Saharan Africa. It offers the potential to enhance tax compliance, reduce tax evasion, simplify tax procedures, and improve revenue mobilization. Nguimkeu and Okou (2021) suggested that digital technologies could help formalize the informal sector, boost productivity, and increase tax revenue in Sub-Saharan Africa. Additionally, Arthur et al. (2021) noted that the adoption of digital platforms could enhance revenue mobilization from the digital economy in post-COVID-19 Africa.

Conclusion:
In conclusion, the provision of technologies for digitalization of tax administration in Sub-Saharan Africa presents numerous opportunities, challenges, and promises. The adoption of digital platforms and technologies could enhance tax compliance, reduce tax evasion, simplify tax procedures, and improve revenue mobilization. However, there are also challenges such as inadequate infrastructure, policy gaps, limited access to digital technologies, and lack of digital literacy that must be addressed. Policymakers should prioritize the provision of digital technologies, while also ensuring equitable access and addressing the challenges and limitations of digitalization.
